name: Abraham Wolf Hirschhorn

info: Abraham Wolf Hirschhorn is the patriarch and oldest known member of the Hirschhorn Family. He was born about 1795 and died on March 11, 1863 in Rzeszow Poland, where he likely spent most, if not all, of his life. He was married to Lea and together they had four children that we know of: Sara Hirschhorn Verstaendig, Scheindel Rachel Hirschhorn Klinger, Isak Salamon Hirschhorn, and Gruene Hirschhorn Both.

name: Lea
children: Sara Hirschhorn, Scheindel Rachel Hirschhorn, Isaac Salomon Hirschhorn, Gruene Hirschhorn
info: Lea was the wife of Abraham Wolf Hirschhorn and the mother of Sara Hirschhorn Verstaendig, Scheindel Rachel Hirschhorn Klinger, Isak Salomon Hirschhorn, and Gruene Hirschhorn Both. Not much else is known about her, aside from the fact that she spent most, if not all, of her life in Rzeszow, Poland.

name: Sara Hirschhorn
children: Chaskel Hersch Verstaendig, Salomon Verstaendig, Ester Verstaendig, Hania Verstaendig, Ephroim Verstaendig, Itta Chana Verstaendig, Abraham Adolf Verstaendig, Eliasz Verstaendig, Hirsch Verstaendig, Riwe Emilia Verstaendig
info: Sara Hirschhorn was the oldest known child of Abraham Wolf and Lea Hirschhorn. She was born about 1831 in Rzeszow, Poland. She was married to Moses Verstaendig, and the pair had ten children that we know of: Chaskel Hersch, Salomon, Ester, Hania, Ephroim, Itta Chana, Abraham Adolf, Eliasz, Hirsch, and Riwe Emilia. She is listed as living in Rzeszow, Poland, in both the 1880 and 1890 censuses. In one record from 1895, after her husband's death, she was recorded as being a Real Estate Owner in Rzeszow. She died on June 17, 1909 in Rzeszow, Poland, at the age of 79.

name: Moses Verstaendig
children: Chaskel Hersch Verstaendig, Salomon Verstaendig, Ester Verstaendig, Hania Verstaendig, Ephroim Verstaendig, Itta Chana Verstaendig, Abraham Adolf Verstaendig, Eliasz Verstaendig, Hirsch Verstaendig, Riwe Emilia Verstaendig
info: Moses Verstaendig was the husband of Sara Hirschhorn, the oldest daughter of Abraham Wolf and Lea Hirschhorn. He was born about 1823 in Rzeszow, Poland, and died there on April 20, 1885, at the age of 62. He had ten children (that we know of) with Sara Hirschhorn, five of whom survived into adulthood, all born in Rzeszow. He was a merchant, and is listed as living in Rzeszow, Poland in the 1880 census. He likely lived most, if not all, of his life in there.

name: Chaskel Hersch Verstaendig
info: Chaskel Hersch Verstaendig was the first-born child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. He was born on August 30, 1856 in Rzeszow, Poland, and died on October 23, 1856 in Rzeszow, Poland, at just about 2 months old.

name: Salomon Verstaendig
children: Chaim Verstaendig, Juda Verstaendig, Abraham Verstaendig, Jakob Verstaendig, Beile Leie Verstaendig, Naftali Verstaendig, Mojzesz Verstaendig
info: Salomon Verstaendig was the second-born child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn, and the oldest to survive into adulthood. He was born on December 10, 1857 in Rzeszow, Poland, and died in 1925 in Rzeszow at 67 years old. On March 4, 1881, Salomon married Ette Hirschfeld in Rzeszow, Poland, where they lived were noted as living in the 1880, 1890, 1902, and 1910 censuses. This was their official civil marriage, but they had likely had a religious marriage ceremony much earlier, around 1874, before the births of any of their children. The couple had seven children: Chaim, Juda, Abraham, Jakob, Beile Leie, Naftali, and Mojzesz.

name: Ette Hirschfeld
children: Chaim Verstaendig, Juda Verstaendig, Abraham Verstaendig, Jakob Verstaendig, Beile Leie Verstaendig, Naftali Verstaendig, Mojzesz Verstaendig
info: Ette Herschfeld was the wife of Salomon Verstaendig. She was born in 1858 in Lezajsk, Poland. She lived in Rzeszow, Poland, where she married Salomon on March 4, 1881, although they likely had a religious ceremony around 1874, before the births of any of their seven. She was noted as living in Rzeszow, Poland, in the 1880, 1890, 1902, and 1910 censuses. She died sometime after 1910, but when exactly is unknown.

name: Chaim Verstaendig
children: Julia Agate Verstaendig, Edwin Jakob Verstaendig
info: Chaim Verstaendig, who also went by Joachim or Jan, was the first child of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. He was born on April 10, 1876 in Rzeszow, Poland, and was noted as living there in the 1880, 1890, and 1902 censuses. He married Roza Alexandrowicz on September 5, 1905 in what was then called Sambor, in the Austrian Empire, but is now Sambir, in Ukraine. It is unkown when Chaim died. He and Roza had two children that we know of, Julia Agate and Edwin Jakob.

name: Roza Alexandrowicz
children: Julia Agate Verstaendig, Edwin Jakob Verstaendig
info: Roza, or Rozalia, Alexandrowicz was the wife of Chaim Verstaendig. She was born on September 22, 1884 in Przemysl, Poland, to Saul Alexandrowicz and Sara Nechelles. She married Chaim on September 5, 1905 in what was then Sambor, in the Austrian Empire, but is now Sambir, Ukraine, and had two children with him that we know of, Julia Agate and Edwin Jakob.

name: Julia Agate Verstaendig
children: Michael Steven Kotowicz
info: Julia Agate Verstaendig was the older of the two children of Chaim Verstaendig and Roza Alexandrowicz. She was born on June 30, 1906 in Sambor, which is now Sambir in the Lviv region of Ukraine, and died in Warsaw, Poland, on September 16, 2000. She married Bronislaw Emil Kotowicz, and had one son that we know of, Michael Steven.

info: Bronislaw Emil Kotowicz was the husband was Julia Agate Verstaendig. He was born on November 3, 1898, in Sambor, which is now Sambir, Ukraine, to Mauricy Kotowicz and Frania Schenker. He died on December 8, 1969, in Frankfurt, Germany. He had one child that we know of with Julia, a son named Michael Steven.

name: Michael Steven Kotowicz
info: Michael Steven Kotowicz, born Michal, was the only child of Bronislaw Emil Kotowicz and Julia Agate Verstaendig. He was born on August 14, 1932, in what was then Lwow, Poland, but is now Lviv, Ukraine, and died on October 15, 2002. It is unclear if he ever married or had children.

name: Edwin Jakob Verstaendig
info: Edwin Jakob Verstaendig was the younger child of Chaim Verstaendig and Roza Alexandrowicz. He was born on May 9, 1912, in Sambor, which is now Sambir, Ukraine. It is unclear if he ever married or had children, or when he died.

name: Juda Verstaendig
info: Juda Verstaendig, who also might have used the name Leib or Leon, was the second son of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. He was born on May 17, 1877 in Rzeszow, Poland. He was noted as living in Rzeszow on the 1880, 1890, and 1902 censuses. It is unknown if he ever married or had children, or when he died.

name: Abraham Verstaendig
children: Edmund Verstaendig
info: Abraham Verstaendig, also known by his secular name Adolf, or Adolfo, was the third son of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. He was born about April 1878 in Rzeszow, Poland, and was noted as living there in the 1880, 1890, 1902, and 1910 censuses. He married Chane Rager on July 17, 1910, in Tarnow, Poland, and at some point the pair moved to Mödling, Austria, where they had one child, Edmund, in 1915. It is unknown when he died.

name: Chane Rager
children: Edmund Verstaendig
info: Chane Rager, who also went by the secular name Anna, was the wife of Abraham (Adolf) Verstaendig. She was born about November 1887 in Sieniawa, Poland, the oldest child of Majer Rager and Hinda Engelberg. She married Abraham on July 17, 1910, in Tarnow, Poland, and was noted as living with him in Rzeszow, Poland, in the 1910 census. Sometime not long after, they moved to Mödling, Austria, where they had one son, Edmund, in 1915.

name: Edmund Verstaendig
info:
Edmund Verstendig was the only child of Abraham Verstaendig and Chane Rager. Born on September 25, 1915, in Mödling, Austria, Edmund was a pharmacist, as well as a skilled painter. He is recorded as living in Rimini, Italy, in 1940, and although it is unclear when he first arrived there, it was no earlier than 1938. Edmund, who went by the name Edmondo while in Italy, was one of just 23 Jews living in Rimini as of December 16, 1943. By July of 1940, he was interned in the Ferramonti di Tarsia internment camp in Tarsia, Italy. While interned, Edmund was able to receive financial assistance from the diocese of Rossano Calabro, which he would send to his mother, who remained in Poland. Edmund had learned to speak fluent Italian during his time in Rimini, and found work in the camp as a painter and photographer, while helping to put on theatrical activities during Jewish religious celebrations.

Edmund remained in the internment camp through the first few months of 1944. It is there that he met Margerita Ehrenfeld, a Jew from Vienna who had arrived at the camp with her parents in 1942 after being saved by the Italian Navy when an attempt to flee to Palestine ended in a shipwreck. They were married quickly, but the marriage was short-lived, ending in divorce around 1942 when Edmund decided to convert to Catholicism and get baptized, against the wishes of his wife. The two did not have any children together.

After liberation from the Ferramonti internment camp, Edmund was settled in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) camp in Bari, Italy on August 16, 1944. He remained there until at least June 26, 1946, after which it is unclear what happened to him. It is known that he intended to move to the United States, but whether or not he actually followed through with that or not is unclear. It is unknown if Edmund ever remarried or had any children, or when he died.

name: Margerita Ehrenfeld
info:
Margerita Ehrenfeld, also known as Marketta, or "Grete" for short, was the wife of Edmund Verstaendig. She was born on July 24, 1922, in Vienna, Austria, to Josef Ehrenfeld and Rosa Hindels, Slovakian Jews. She had one older brother, Fritz (Philipp) Ehrenfeld.

In the summer of 1940, along with her parents and over 400 other Slovakian Jews, Margerita attempted to flee from the rising antisemitism in Europe to Palestine. Departing from Bratislava, Slovakia, on May 18, 1940 aboard the S.S. Pentcho, they set sail down the Danube River, stopping in Sulina, Romania, to pick up about 100 Austrian Jews, bringing the total number of passengers to over 500. They left Sulina on September 21, 1940, crossing the Black Sea and arriving at the Greek port of Mitilini, on the island of Lesbos. However, the ship was forced to leave port without refueling. The passengers contacted the Committee for the Relief of Refugees (CRR) in Athens to explain their situation, and were allowed to restock in Piraeus, Greece, just outside of Athens.

Leaving Piraeus on October 3, 1940, they reached Rhodes, Greece, four days later, and were allowed to restock again but were ordered to leave the next day. On October 9, the ship's boiler exploded while at sea, and the ship broke in two off the coast of Kamilonissi, a deserted island under Italian control. The passengers were able to reach shore, along with their supplies, before the S.S. Pentcho sank. A few men took the only lifeboat to look for help, and were eventually rescued by a British ship. When the CRR learned of what had happened, they had supplies delivered to the island with the help of the Greeks. On October 18 and 19, Italian authorities picked up the stranded refugees and took them to Rhodes, where they remained in a makeshift camp for the next year and a quarter. Finally, in January 1942, they were transferred to the Ferramonti di Tarsia internment camp in Tarsia, Italy, near Cosenza, Calabria, Italy, where they remained until the liberation of Italy by the Allied Forces in 1944.

It was there that Margerita met and married Edmund in about 1942, although their marriage was short-lived, as they divorced when Edmund converted to Catholicism against Margarita's wishes, in about 1944. By May of that year, Margarita's parents, along with eventually the large majority of the other passengers of the S.S. Pentcho, finally made it to Palestine. Margerita, however, was settled in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) camp in Bari, Italy, where she remained until at least June 26, 1946. There, she met and married her second husband, Adolf Sebald Kellner, and the two were able to immigrate to the United States, where in 1948 they had a daughter, Ruth Ida Kellner. Margerita, who spelled her name Margaretha in the U.S., died on May 28, 1991, in Queens, New York.

name: Jakob Verstaendig
children: Juliusz Verstaendig, Zigmund Verstaendig, Marjan Jozef Verstaendig
info: Jakob Verstaendig, also called Yaakov, was the fourth son of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. He was born on June 28, 1879 in Rzeszow, Poland, and died of disease on November 11, 1939 in Rzeszow, Poland. He is recorded as living in Rzeszow, where he was a merchant, in the 1880, 1890, 1902, and 1910 censuses, and likely lived there his whole life. He married Rachela Lea Maler on February 20, 1910, in her hometown of Przemysl, Poland, and together they had three sons: Juliusz, Zigmund, and Marjan Jozef.

name: Rachela Lea Maler
children: Juliusz Verstaendig, Zigmund Verstaendig, Marjan Jozef Verstaendig
info: Rachela Lea Maler was the wife of Jakob Verstaendig. She was born on July 22, 1890 in Przemysl, Poland, to Boruch Maler and Mariem Stabenhaus and died in 1931 in Rzeszow, Poland. On February 20, 1910, she married Jakob in Przemysl, and was then listed as living in Rzeszow with her husband on the 1910 census. Together, they had three sons: Juliusz, Zigmund, and Marjan Jozef.

name: Juliusz Verstaendig
info: Juliusz Verstaendig was the oldest son of Jakob Verstaendig and Rachela Lea Maler. He was born in 1911 in Rzeszow, Poland, and died in 1941 during the Holocaust. It is unclear if he was married or had children at the time of his death, but it is unlikely.

name: Zigmund Verstaendig
info: Zigmund Verstaendig was the middle son of Jakob Verstaendig and Rachela Lea Maler. He was born about 1919 in Poland, likely in Rzeszow, and died during the Holocaust in 1945 in Tarnow, Poland. It is unclear if he was married or had children at the time of his death, but it is unlikely.

name: Marjan Jozef Verstaendig
info: Marjan Jozef Verstaendig was the youngest son of Jakob Verstaendig and Rachela Lea Maler. He was born in Rzeszow, Poland in 1919. It is unclear what happened to him after that, if he ever married or had children, or when he died.

name: Beile Leie Verstaendig
info: Beile Leie Verstaendig was the fifth child, and only daughter, of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. She was born on September 25, 1880 in Rzeszow, Poland. She lived until at least the age of 10, as she appeared on both the 1880 and 1890 censuses of Rzeszow, but it is not known what happened to her after that, if she ever married or had kids, or when she died.

name: Naftali Verstaendig
children: Sidonie Verstaendig, Lee Roy Taylor
info: Naftali Verstaendig was the sixth child of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. He was born on April 11, 1882 in Rzeszow, Poland. At some point he moved to Vienna, Austria, where on August 17, 1913, he married Josephine "Pepi" Gerstl at the Leopoldstädter Tempel, a synagogue on Tempelgasse ("Temple Alley"). He fought as an infantryman for the Austro-Hungarian Empire in World War I, and on January 28, 1916 was injured in Beresovka, Transbaikalia Region, Russia. He survived his casualty, however, and in 1919 his wife gave birth to twins, Sidonie and Leopold Verstaendig  (the latter of which later changed his name to Lee Roy Taylor), their only two children aside from a stillborn daughter in 1914. During the Holocaust, he and his wife were deported from Vienna to the Jungfernhof concentration camp in Riga, Latvia, on December 3, 1941. He likely died there not long after, probably in 1942.

name: Josephine Gerstl
children: Sidonie Verstaendig, Lee Roy Taylor
info: Josephine Gerstl, nicknamed "Pepi," a common nickname for Josephine, was the wife of Naftali Verstaendig. She was born on September 17, 1883, in Weingrabe, Austria, to Markus and Sali Gerstl. She and Naftali married on August 17, 1913, in Vienna, Austria, and gave birth to a stillborn daughter in 1914. After her husband's military service in World War I ended, the pair had twins, Sidonie and Leopold Verstaendig (the latter of which later changed his name to Lee Roy Taylor). During the Holocaust, she and her husband were deported on December 3, 1941 from Vienna, Austria to the Jungfernhof concentration camp in Riga, Latvia. She likely died there not long after, probably in 1942.

name: Sidonie Verstaendig
info: Sidonie Verstaendig was the only daughter of Naftali Verstaendig and Josephine "Pepi" Gerstl, and the twin sister of Leopold. She was born on June 29, 1919 in Vienna, Austria. Although it is not certain, it is likely she died at a young age, because no records could be found of her after her birth.

name: Lee Roy Taylor
children: Susan Kay Taylor
info:
Lee Roy Taylor was born with the name Leopold Verstaendig, the only son of Naftali Verstaendig and Pepi Gerstl, and the twin sister of Sidonie. He was born on June 29, 1919 in Vienna, Austria. Described as being 5'6" in height and of medium complexion, with brown hair and blue eyes, Leopold worked as a tailor. In 1939, he fled the rising antisemitism of the Nazi party, and was one of about 4,000 mostly Austrian and German Jewish men who received passage and accomodation in England. He lived in the Kitchener Camp in Sandwich, Kent, England, which was used to house male Jewish refugees and which was one of seven military camps that collectively were called Richborough Port.

Leopold spent no more than a year in the Kitchener Camp, however, as on January 14, 1940, at the age of 20, he set sail from Liverpool, England aboard the S.S. Samaria. After a twelve day journey, he arrived on January 26, 1940 at Ellis Island in New York. On the ship manifest, Leopold noted that his passage was paid for by a friend of his named Arde Bulova, who was also listed as Leopold's closest friend/relative in his destination country. It is unclear how he knew Arde Bulova, who was born in America to Czech immigrants. Bulova lived on Fifth Avenue in New York City and was a well-known businessman and watch-manufacturer who ran the Bulova Watch Company, which made watches and other time-keeping devices. One guess as to their relationship is that Leopold was hired as an employee by Bulova, which could explain why Bulova paid for Leopold's passage to the U.S. and why Leopold listed Bulova as his closest contact in the U.S.

It is unclear how long, or even if, he worked for Arde Bulova, as on October 16, 1940, Leopold registered for the World War II U.S. Army draft in Cairo, Illinois, and it can be assumed that by this point he was living in Illinois. He entered military service on April 16, 1941 in Chanute Field, Illinois, a U.S. Army Air Forces base, and served for some period of time as a Sergeant, though it is unclear where he served. Less than two years later, on June 30, 1942 in Chanute Field, Illinois, Leopold became a naturalized citizen of the United States of America. By this point, or upon his naturalization, his name was changed by court order to Lee Roy Taylor. It is unclear why he changed his name, aside from the fact that the name Verstaendig probably stood out in a place like Illinois, while a name like Lee Roy Taylor sounded more American in a time of increased antisemitism.

On March 17, 1943, Lee Roy married Katherine Lucille Becker in St. Louis, Missouri. The two lived in Memphis, Tennessee for at least some time in 1945, when they had a daughter, Susan Kay. However, their daughter only lived for about two weeks. Lee Roy died on July 17, 1977 in St. Louis, Missouri, at the age of 58. He was buried alongside his wife at the Bellerive Gardens Cemetery in Creve Coeur, Missouri, the same cemetery where the famous baseball player Stan Musial is buried, as well as the legendary musician Chuck Berry.

name: Katherine Lucille Becker
children: Susan Kay Taylor
info: Katherine Lucille Becker was the wife of Lee Roy Taylor. She was born October 12, 1917 in Marissa, Illinois to German immigrants Julius Becker and Josephine Blumer, and was the second of their six children. She married Lee Roy on March 17, 1943, in St. Louis, Missouri, and sometime after the two moved to Memphis, Tennessee. There, she gave birth to the couple's only daughter, Susan Kay, however she only lived for about two weeks. Katherine spent most of her life in St. Louis, Missouri, and died in May of 1977, just two months before her husband.

name: Susan Kay Taylor
info: Susan Kay Taylor was the only child of Lee Roy Taylor and Katherine Lucille Becker. She was born on February 6, 1945 in Memphis, Tennessee, and died at just about two weeks old on February 18, 1945, in Memphis, Tennessee.

name: Mojzesz Verstaendig
info: Mojzesz Verstaendig was the seventh and final child of Salomon Verstaendig and Ette Hirschfeld. He was born on September 10, 1885, in Rzeszow, Poland. He lived until at least about 17 years old, as he appeared on both the 1890 and 1902 Rzeszow censuses living with his family. However, it is unclear what happened to him after that, if he ever married or had children, or when he died.

name: Ester Verstaendig
info: Ester Verstaendig was the third child, and the first daughter, of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. She was born on August 26, 1859, in Rzeszow, Poland, and died there about four months later, on December 19, 1859.

name: Hania Verstaendig
info: Hania Verstaendig was the fourth child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. She was born in 1860 in Rzeszow, Poland. It is unknown when she died, but it is likely she did not survive into adulthood, as she did not appear with her family in any of the Rzeszow census records available.

name: Ephroim Verstaendig
info: Ephroim Verstaendig was the fifth child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. He was born on November 18, 1861 in Rzeszow, Poland, and died there three weeks later on December 8, 1861.

name: Itta Chana Verstaendig
children: Lea Leontyna Weisglas, Barbara Weisglas, Hermina Weisglas, Moritz Weisglas, Jacob Weisglas
info: Itta Chana Verstaendig was the sixth child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. She was born on May 19, 1865 in Rzeszow, Poland, and was recorded as living there on the 1880 Rzeszow census. She married Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas on October 28, 1884 in what was then Lwow, Poland, but is now Lviv, Ukraine, at 19 years old, and went on to have six children with him: Lea Leontyna, Barbara, Hermina, Margaretta, Moritz, and Jacob. Itta died in about 1937 in what was then Mszaniec, Poland, but is now Mshanets, in the Lviv region of Ukraine.

name: Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas
children: Lea Leontyna Weisglas, Barbara Weisglas, Hermina Weisglas, Moritz Weisglas, Jacob Weisglas
info: Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas was the husband of Itta Chana Verstaendig. He was born about 1859 to Natan and Malka Weisglas in what was then Tarnopol, in the Austrian Empire, but is now Ternopil, Ukraine. He was 25 years old at his marriage on October 28, 1884, in what was then Lwow, Poland, but is now Lviv, Ukraine. The two had six children together: Lea Leontyna, Barbara, Hermina, Margaretta, Moritz, and Jacob. Seweryn Szebsel died about 1929 in what was then called Mszaniec, Poland but is now Mshanets, Ukraine.

name: Lea Leontyna Weisglas
info: Lea Leontyna Weisglas was the first born child of Seweryn Weisglas and Itta Chana Verstaendig. She was born on January 3, 1886, in what was then called Olexince, which is most likely the modern-day Oleszyce, in Podkarpackie, Poland. She married Marek Wolf Finkler at the age of 22 on March 15, 1908 in what was then Lwow, Poland, but is now Lviv, Ukraine. It is unknown if the two had any children, or when Lea died.

name: Marek Wolf Finkler
info: Marek Wolf Finkler was the husband of Lea Leontyna Weisglas. He was born to Abraham Izak Finkler and Bascha Breindel Silberstein in late October of 1870 in what was then Lwow, in the Austrian Empire, but is now Lviv, Ukraine. He had one older sister, Pesche Finkler. He was 37 years old when he got married on March 15, 1908, in Lwow. It is unknown if the couple had any children, or when he died.

name: Barbara Weisglas
info: Barbara Weisglas was the second child of Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas and Itta Chana Verstaendig. She was born on April 22, 1890 in a town that was then called Mszaniec but is now Mshanets, Ukraine. It is unclear if she ever married or had children, or when she died.

name: Hermina Weisglas
children: Walter Lowen, Stefania Teresa Lowenherz
info: Hermina Weisglas, who also might have used the name Regina, was the third child of Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas and Itta Chana Verstaendig. She was born on September 23, 1893 in what was then Mszaniec, but is now Mshanets, Ukraine. At some point, she moved to Vienna, Austria, where she met and married Markus Loewenherz at the Leopoldstädter Tempel on March 21, 1915. The pair had two children together, Wladyslaw (who later changed his name to Walter Lowen) and Stefania Teresa. Hermina was killed during the Holocaust in about 1942, in what was the Lwow region of Poland but is now the Lviv region of Ukraine.

name: Markus Lowenherz
children: Walter Lowen, Stefania Teresa Lowenherz
info: Markus Lowenherz was the husband of Hermina Weisglas. He was born on March 22, 1888 in what was Lwow, Poland, but is now Lviv Ukraine, in a town which may be in modern-day Ukraine. He was the son of Abraham Leib Lowenherz and Amelia Jampoler. At some point, he moved to Vienna, Austria, where he married his wife on March 21, 1915 at the Leopoldstädter Tempel. Together, they had one son, Wladylsaw (who later changed his name to Walter Lowen), and one daughter, Stefania Teresa. Markus was killed during the Holocaust in about 1943, in what was the Lwow region of Poland but is now the Lviv region of Ukraine.

name: Walter Lowen
children: Norma Lowen, Mark Lowen, Richard J. Lowen
info:
Walter Lowen, born Wladyslaw Lowenherz, was the older child, and only son, of Markus Lowenherz and Hermina Weisglas. He was born on March 10, 1916 in Vienna, Austria, but spent most of his childhood in the Lwow region of Poland, where his parents were from. He was a national junior table tennis champion, and helped Poland win bronze at the 1935 Swaythling Cup World Table Tennis Championships in London. Due to the rise of antisemitism and Nazism, Wladyslaw immigrated to Australia in July of 1939, just months before he would have received his medical degree from the Universtiy of Lwow. However, in 1940 he was accepted into the medical school at the University of Melbourne.

At some point after arriving in Australia, Wladyslaw changed his name to Walter Lowen. In 1941, he married his wife Sima Segan in Victoria, Australia, who he had met on the way to Australia. He continued to play table tennis in Australia, and won the Australian open singles title in 1948, as well as four Victoria Open singles championships between 1941 and 1950. During this time, he also graduated from medical school in 1945, going on to work as a doctor in Melbourne until his retirement in 1994. Later in life, he started focusing on competitive bridge. He became a Grand Master and helped team Victoria win the the 1972 Australian National Bridge Championships.

Walter and Sima had three children together: Norma, Mark, and Richard. Walter lived a long life, dying at the age of 94 on January 11, 2011 in Melbourne, Australia. He was buried the next day at the Melbourne Chevra Kadisha Springvale Cemetery.

name: Sima Segan
children: Norma Lowen, Mark Lowen, Richard J. Lowen
info: Sima Segan, born Sima Cygielnicki, was the wife of Walter Lowen. She was born on July 29, 1919 somewhere in Eastern Europe, to David and Sonia Segan. She had a brother named Berek and a sister named Riva. In 1939, she immigrated to Australia to flee religious persecution in Europe, meeting Walter on the way there. The two married not long after, in 1941 in Victoria, Australia. She had three children: Norma, Mark, and Richard. She died at 99 years old, on August 27, 2018, in Melbourne, Australia, and was buried two days later next to her husband at the Melbourne Chevra Kadisha Springvale Cemetery.

name: Norma Lowen
children: Paul Gilbert, Michael Gilbert, Danielle Gilbert
info: Norma Lowen is the oldest child, and only daughter, of Walter Lowen and Sima Segan. She is married to Warwick Gilbert, and they have three children together: Paul, Danielle, and Michael. She lives in Australia.

name: Stefania Teresa Lowenherz
info: Stefania Teresa Lowenherz was the younger child, and only daughter, of Markus Lowenherz and Hermina Weisglas. She was born on December 11, 1925 in what is now Lviv, Ukraine, but was then the Lwow, Poland. At some point, she immigrated to Australia, following her older brother. It is there that she met Jerzy Lechoslaw Olszynski, who she married in 1953 in Victoria, Australia. It is possible that she was married once before Jerzy, but it is unclear. She had two daughters with Jerzy, Mary and Janet. On January 29, 1957, Stefania was declared a naturalized citizen of Australia, along with her husband. At that time, they were living in Hawthorn, Victoria, Australia. Stefania died on January 22, 2018, in Victoria, Australia.

name: Jerzy Lechoslaw Olszynski

He was born on May 11, 1918, likely in Poland, to Boleslaw and Janina Olszynski, and immigrated to Australia. He married his wife in 1953 in Victoria, Australia, and became a naturalized Australian citizen on January 29, 1957. At that time, he was living in Hawthorn, Victoria, Australia. Jerzy and Stefania had two daughters, Mary and Janet. Jerzy died in December of 2014 in Victoria, Australia.

name: Margaretta Weisglas

info: Margaretta, or Malgorzata, Weisglas was the fourth child of Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas and Itta Chana Verstaendig. She was born on May 5, 1896 in Mszaniec, Poland, which is now Mshanets, Ukraine. Margaretta was a doctor, earning her degree from the Lwow University of Medicine (now the University of Lviv) on January 3, 1924. On May 2, 1926, she married Bernard Berisch Goldstein in what was then Zborow, Poland, but is now the city of Zboriv in the Ternopil region of Ukraine. They had one daughter, Seweryna, named after Margaretta's father. By 1941, she had been widowed, and she and her daughter lived in Husiatyn, Poland, which is now Husyatyn, Ukraine. There, she worked as a doctor. It is unknown when Margaretta died, although it is likely she did not survive the Holocaust.

name: Bernard Berisch Goldstein

info: Bernard Berisch Goldstein was the husband of Margaretta Weisglas. He was born on January 21, 1892, in what was then Brzezany, Poland, but is now Berezhany, in the Ternopil region of Ukraine. His parents were Feibisch Goldstein and Breine Blau. He was a doctor, like his wife, who he married on May 2, 1926, in what was then Zborow, Poland, but is now Zboriv, Ukraine. They had one daughter Seweryna. Bernard died sometime before 1941, although exactly when is unclear.

name: Seweryna Goldstein
info: Seweryna, or Severine, Goldstein was the only child of Bernard Berisch Goldstein and Margaretta Weisglas. She was born in 1927 in what was then Tarnopol, Poland, but is now Ternopil, Ukraine. By 1941, at the age of 14, she lived in Husiatyn, Poland (now Husyatyn, Ukraine) with her mother, who worked there as a doctor. Her father had by then passed away, although when exactly is unclear. It is unknown if Seweryna ever married or had children, or when she died, although it is likely she did not survive the Holocaust.

name: Moritz Weisglas
info: Moritz Weisglas, also known as Moshe, was fifth child, and oldest son, of Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas and Itta Chana Verstaendig. He was born on June 25, 1897 in Mszaniec, Poland (now Mshanets, Ukraine). On July 3, 1927, he married Julia Yehudit Dimant in Tarnopol, Poland (now Ternopil, Ukraine), but it is unclear if they ever had any children. Moritz survived the Holocaust, but it is unknown what happened to him afterward, or when he died.

name: Julia Yehudit Dimant
info: Julia Yehudit Dimant was the wife of Moritz Weisglas. She was born on April 16, 1905 in what was then Sniatyn, Poland (now Snyatyn, Ukraine) to Moritz Dimant, an engineer, and Regina Rivka Margolis. She had one brother, Zhigmunt Dimant. She married her husband on July 3, 1927, in Tarnopol, Poland (now Ternopil, Ukraine), but it is unclear if they ever had any children. Julia was killed during the Holocaust in 1942, somewhere in the Lwow region of Poland.

name: Jacob Weisglas
info: Jacob Weisglas, also known as Yaakov, was the youngest child of Seweryn Szebsel Weisglas and Itta Chana Verstaendig. He was born on May 1, 1899 in Mszaniec, Poland (now Mshanets, Ukraine). He worked as an agriculturalist, and was killed during the Holocaust, although exactly when or where is unclear. It is also unknown if he ever married or had children.

name: Abraham Adolf Verstaendig

info: Abraham Adolf Verstaendig was the seventh child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. He was born on December 27, 1866 in Rzeszow, Poland. At some point, he moved to Vienna, Austria, where he met Jenny Lowy. The two were married on August 25, 1901, at the Stadttempel, a synagogue in the Innere Stadt (1st district) of Vienna. They had two daughters together, Kitty and Vally (who later changed her name to Valerie Verstin). Abraham lived until the age of 72, when he died on February 21, 1939, in Vienna, Austria.

name: Jenny Lowy

info: Jenny Lowy was the wife of Abraham adolf Verstaendig. She was born on March 31, 1867 in Vienna, Austria to Max Lowy and Caroline Benedikt, the sixth of their nine children, with five sisters and three brothers. She married Abraham on August 25, 1901 in Vienna, and soon had two daughters, Kitty and Vally (who later changed her name to Valerie Verstin). Jenny also ran a laundry shop in Vienna. On December 24, 1923, she resigned from the Vienna Jewish Community, the IKG (Israelitische Kultusgemeinde Wien). Jenny died on March 1, 1930, in Vienna, Austria.

name: Kitty Verstaendig
info:
Kitty Verstaendig was the older daughter of Abraham Adolf Verstaendig and Jenny Lowy. She was born on December 12, 1903, in Vienna, Austria. She studied Montessori education and, early on in her career, taught at the Vienna House of Children. She was also a member of the Theosophical Society, and after attending the group's 50th anniversary in 1925 in Madras, India, (now Chennai), she decided to remain in India to work in the education system there. She started as the head of a Montessori school in Varanasi, India before establishing another Montessori school in Allahabad, India, in 1927. There, she befriended the influential Nehru family and, in 1929, married the Indian journalist and politician Benegal Shiva Rao. Kitty would occasionally travel to Germany to visit schools and learn about the latest developments in education. Her connections in India and Germany allowed her to help numerous Jews escape persecution and resettle in India.

Kitty continued to study child education, and advocated for the needs of children as well as women in the field. She got involved in the Indian women's rights movement by joining the All India Women's Conference, leading the Social and Legislation Section at their conferences in both 1941 and 1945 and becoming an important member of the group. She was appointed to lead a committee in charge of deciding what women expected from the new Constitution of India, and led the drafting of an Indian Women's Charter of Rights and Duties.

Kitty continued to promote causes related to women's and children's rights. Following the partition of India and Pakistan in 1947, Kitty helped find employment for refugee women and was a large supporter and promoter of Indian handicrafts and textiles, serving as the Vice President of the All India Handicrafts Board. In addition, she pioneered the Indian Council for Child Welfare, and was influential in the passing of the Hindu code bills, which reformed the laws of India towards a common law code instead of being based on religious law. The bills were implemented by the Indian National Congress in the 1950s, led by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. The reforms led to major advancements in the rights of women in the country.

Kitty and her husband did not have any children. She died on February 9, 1980, in Bangalore, India, at the age of 76.

name: Benegal Shiva Rao
info:
Benegal Shiva Rao was the husband of Kitty Verstaendig. He was born on February 26, 1891, in Mangalore, India, to Benegal Raghavendra Rao and Radhabai. His father was a renowned medical practitioner. Benegal Shiva Rao was the youngest of four sons. One older brother was Benegal Narsing Rau, an Indian diplomat, jurist, and politician who was deeply involved in the creation of the Constitution of India. He was also India's representative to the United Nations Security Council from 1950-1952, of which he served as the president in 1950. He was later a judge on the International Court of Justice from 1952-1954. Another brother, Benegal Rama Rau, who served as India's ambassador to both Japan (1947-1948) and the United States (1948-1949), and was also the 4th Governor of the Reserve Bank of India (1949-1957).

Benegal Shiva Rao was an Indian journalist and politician from an important and well-respected family. After graduating from Presidency College, Chennai, he joined the labor movement, and then the Theosophical Society, of which his wife, who he married in 1929, was also a member. He wrote for newspapers such as The Hindu, an Indian paper, and The Manchester Guardian (now The Guardian), a British paper. Benegal Shiva Rao continued his work in the international labor movement, serving as a delegate to both the International Labour Organization and the United Nations, to which he led the Indian Delegation for four straight years, from 1947-1950. He was a member of both chambers of the Indian Parliament as a representative for South Kanara (which later became the seat representing Mangalore in 1957, and then Dakshida Kannada in 2008), serving in the lower chamber (the Lok Sabha) from 1952-1957, and then the upper chamber (the Rajya Sabha) from 1957-1960. He then retired, choosing to focus his time on his research, writing and contributing to numerous books, collections, and other publications.

Benegal Shiva Rao died on December 15, 1975 in Delhi, India. He was survived by his wife, but the two had no children together.

name: Valerie Verstin
info: Valerie Verstin, born Vally Verstaendig, was the younger daughter of Abraham Verstaendig and Jenny Lowy. She was born on December 11, 1905, in Vienna, Austria. On July 24, 1937, Vally resigned from the Vienna Jewish Community, the IKG (Israelitische Kultusgemeinde Wien). It was upon her resignation that she changed her name. Valerie's occupation was listed as a poetess. It is unknown if she ever married or had children, or when she died.

name: Eliasz Verstaendig
info: Eliasz Verstaendig was the eighth child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. He was born on February 3, 1868 in Rzeszow, Poland. He is noted as living with his family in Rzeszow in the 1880 and 1890 censuses. Starting in 1889, he attended Jagiellonian University in Krakow, Poland, taking time off in early 1892 to serve in the military before earning his Doctor of Medicine degree on November 20, 1895. On December 25, 1898, at the age of 30, he married Malgorzata Steuer in Krakow, Poland. It is unknown if Eliasz and his wife ever had any children. He worked as a doctor, serving as the municipal doctor of the town of Tarnobrzeg, Poland, not far from Rzeszow, until he died there from chronic nephritis on November 9, 1913. He was buried two days later in the Jewish Cemetery of Rzeszow.

name: Malgorzata Steuer
info: Malgorzata Steuer was the wife of Eliasz Verstaendig. She was born about 1879 in Modrzejow, Poland, to Gerschlik Emanuel Steuer and Helena Pniower. She was 19 years old when she married her husband in Krakow on December 25, 1898. It is unknown if she ever had any children, or when she died.

name: Hirsch Verstaendig
info: Hirsch Verstaendig, also known by the secular name Herman, was the ninth child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. He was born on October 27, 1869 in Rzeszow, Poland. He is recorded as living with his family in Rzeszow on the 1880 and 1890 censuses, but it is unclear what happened to him after that, if he ever got married or had children, or when he died.

name: Riwe Emilia Verstaendig
children: Edmund Hass, Ludmila Hass, Gustaw Hass, Julius Hass
info: Riwe Emilia Verstaendig was the tenth and youngest child of Moses Verstaendig and Sara Hirschhorn. She was born in 1872 in Rzeszow, Poland. She is recorded as living in Rzeszow with her family in both the 1880 and 1890 censuses. She married Israel Iser Hass, and together they had four children: Edmund, Ludmila, Gustaw, and Julius. In the late 1890s, they lived in Tarnow, Poland, where her middle two children were born, and by 1907, they were living in what was then Brzezany, but is now Berezhany, Ukraine. At some point, they were also lilving in Sambor, Poland (now Sambir, Ukraine). It is unknown when Riwe Emilia died.

name: Israel Iser Hass
children: Edmund Hass, Ludmila Hass, Gustaw Hass, Julius Hass
info: Israel Iser Hass, also known by the secular name Izydor, was the husband of Riwe Emilia Verstaendig. He was born in about 1863 in Brzezany, Poland (now Berezhany, Ukraine), to Jozef Hass and Sara Neuschal. He had four children with his wife: Edmund, Ludmila, Gustaw, and Julius. At various times he lived in Rzeszow, Tarnow, and Sambor (now Sambir, Ukraine), where he worked as a Treasury Supervisor. He died on December 14, 1925, in Sambor.

name: Edmund Hass
info: Edmund Hass was the first child of Israel Iser Hass and Riwe Emilia Verstaendig. He was born on July 4, 1895 in Rzeszow, Poland, but died only two years later, in 1897 in Tarnow, Poland.

name: Ludmila Hass
info: Ludmila Hass was the second child, and only daughter, of Israel Iser Hass and Riwe Emilia Verstaendig. She was born on July 7, 1896, in Tarnow, Poland. On June 29, 1923, Ludmila married Markus Hillebrand, in what was then Sambor, Poland, but is now Sambir, Ukraine. It is unknown if they ever had any children, or when she died.

name: Markus Hillebrand
info: Markus Hillebrand was the husband of Ludmila Hass. He was born on November 6, 1888 in what was then Stryj, Poland, but is now Stryi, Ukraine, the youngest of three children of Schmerl Hillebrand and Chaje Hendel Rothbaum. Markus lived in Rawa Ruska, Poland (now Rava-Ruska, Ukraine, situated on the border between Ukraine and Poland), where he worked as an attorney and lawyer. He married his wife on June 29, 1923, in Sambor, Poland (now Sambir, Ukraine), but it is unknown if they had any children together. It is also unknown when Markus died.

name: Gustaw Hass
info: Gustaw Hass was the third child of Israel Iser Hass and Riwe Emilia Verstaendig. He was born on March 10, 1899, in Tarnow, Poland. It is unknown if her ever married or had children, or when he died.

name: Julius Hass
info: Julius Hass was the fourth son and youngest child of Israel Iser Hass and Riwe Emilia Verstaendig. He was born on March 9, 1907 in Brzezany, Poland (now Berezhany, Ukraine). He worked as an attorney and lawyer. On April 2, 1939, he married Ester Rosel Wallach in Rzeszow, Poland. The two lived in Lezajsk, Poland. It is unknown if they ever had any children, or when Julius died, but it is likely he and his wife were killed during the Holocaust.

name: Ester Rosel Wallach
info: Ester Rosel Wallach was the wife of Julius Hass. She was born on November 14, 1914, in Duermach, Czech Republic (what this place is called today is not clear). Her parents were Dawid Wallach and Chaja Sura Wetter. She married her husband on April 2, 1939 in Rzeszow, Poland, but they both lived not far away in Lezajsk, Poland. It is unknown if they ever had any children, or when she died, but it is likely she was killed during the Holocaust.

She was married to Meier Isak Klinger, and together they had nine children, at least four of which survived into adulthood: Chane Hene, Feiga Dobre, Juda Leib, Moses, Abraham Wolf, Markus Hirsch, Liebe, Benjamin, and Lena. It is unknown when she died.

name: Chane Hene Klinger
children: Solomon Klinger, Feige Rosa Froschgang, Leja Froschgang, Scheindel Froschgang, Meyer Klinger
info: Chane Hene Klinger (also known as Anna) was the oldest child of Meier Isak Klinger and Scheindel Rachel Hirschhorn. She was born 1857 in Rzeszow, Poland, and was noted as living there with her parents on the 1870 and 1880 censuses. By 1879, she had married Markus Froschgang in a religious ceremony (although not in a civil ceremony, meaning their marriage was not officially recognized by the government), and the pair had five children together: Solomon, Feige Rosa, Leja, Scheindel, and Meyer. They lived in various towns across the Lwow region (now the Podkarpackie region of Poland and the Lviv region of Ukraine), including in Boratyn, Poland (now in Ukraine), Chlopice, Poland, and Biala, near Rzeszow, Poland. It is unknown when Chane Hene died.

name: Markus Froschgang
children: Solomon Klinger, Feige Rosa Froschgang, Leja Froschgang, Scheindel Froschgang, Meyer Klinger
info: Markus Froschgang was the husband of Chane Hene Klinger. He was born about 1855 in Poland to Nachmen and Ruchel Froschgang, and married Chana sometime before 1880 in a religious ceremony, although their marriage was not recognized by the government as they did not have a civil ceremony. They had four children together: Solomon, Feige Rosa, Leja, Scheindel, and Meyer. Markus died at the age of 50 on June 28, 1905 in Boratyn, which was at the time in Poland but is now in Ukraine.

info:
Solomon Klinger, born Salmen Froschgang, was the oldest child of Markus Froschgang and Chane Hene Klinger. He used his mother's last name, Klinger, instead of his father's because his parents were not officially married when he was born, so the government did not recognize his father's paternity. He was born on January 7, 1879, in Boratyn, Poland (now in Ukraine). Sometime in the early 1900s, he met and married Yetta Kessler in a religious ceremony, and she gave birth to their first child, Molly, in 1904.

In 1905, at the age of 36, Solomon and his family emigrated to the United States, departing from Hamburg, Germany on October 18, 1905 aboard the S.S. Blucher, and arriving at the port of New York on October 29, 1905. In the U.S., he went by the nickname Sam, and went to work as a patrolman. His wife and daughter likely followed not long after, and Solomon and Yetta were married in a civil ceremony on December 19, 1906, in Manhattan, New York. Over the next few years they had three more children, Max Henry, Murray, and Lillian, and on April 6, 1915, Solomon was became a naturalized citizen of the United States. 

Solomon was recorded as living in Manhattan in the 1910, 1920, 1930, 1940, and 1950 censuses. However, in 1925, his wife Yetta passed away. Sometime in the next few years, Solomon married Sadie Drucker, another Galician immigrant who had come to the United States with her daughter, Ester Cirl Drucker. It is not known who Ester's father was, as Sadie was never married before. Solomon and Sadie were married in Manhattan on March 30, 1929, and were together until Solomon's died in New York City on January 24, 1952.

info: Yetta Kessler was the first wife of Solomon Klinger. She was born the second of five children of Meyer Hersh Kessler and Beckie Hahn around 1885, somewhere in the Galicia region of Eastern Europe that now encompasses parts of modern-day Poland and Ukraine. At some point in the early 1900s, she married Solomon in a religious ceremony, and gave birth to their first daughter, Molly, in 1904 in Poland. Not long after, she joined her husband in the United States, and the two had an official civil marriage on December 19, 1906, in Manhattan, New York. Once in the United States, the pair had three more children: Max Henry, Murray, and Lillian. Yetta is recorded as living with her husband and children on the 1910, 1915, and 1920 censuses. However, at about 40 years old, she died in Manhattan on June 6, 1925.

name: Molly Klinger
info: Molly Klinger was the first born child of Solomon Klinger and Yetta Kessler. She was born on July 15, 1904, in Jaroslaw, Poland. A year after her birth, her father left for the United States, and Molly and her mother joined him not long after. Molly is recorded as living with her parents and younger siblings in the 1910 and 1915 censuses in Manhattan, New York, but it is unclear what happens to her after that, if she ever married or had children, or when she died.

info: Max Henry Klinger was the second child of Solomon Klinger and Yetta Kessler, their first after immigrating to the United States. He was born on June 2, 1907 in Manhattan, New York, and is recorded as living there with his parents and siblings in the 1910, 1915, 1920, and 1930 censuses. On June 15, 1930, he married Rose Krainer in Brooklyn, New York, and they are recorded as living together in Brooklyn in the 1935, 1940, and 1940 censuses. They had two children together, Justine and Stephen. Max died in Palm Beach, Florida, on January 9, 1992, at the age of 84.

info: Rose Krainer was the wife of Max Henry Klinger. She was born on August 11, 1908, in the Russian Empire to Samuel Krainer and Pearl Pradlord. She immigrated to the United States sometime before 1930, as on June 15 of that year she married her husband in Brooklyn, New York. The two are recorded as living in Brooklyn in the 1935, 1940, and 1950 censuses, and had two children together there, Justine and Stephen. Rose died on October 1, 2001.

name: Justine Klinger

She was born about 1932 in New York, USA, and is recorded as living in Brooklyn, New York with her family in the 1935, 1940, and 1950 censuses. She first married Michael Valenti, and then married Daniel E. Cheifetz in 1985 in Manhattan, New York. Justine lives in New York.

They had two children together, Richard and Amy. At some point they divorced, and in 1985, Daniel married Justine in Manhattan. Daniel died on June 9, 2006, in New York City, New York.

name: Stephen Klinger
info: Stephen Klinger was the second child and only son of Max Henry Klinger and Rose Krainer. He was born about 1947 in New York, USA, and is recorded as living with his family in Brooklyn, New York, in the 1950 census. It is unclear if he ever married or had children. He is still living.

name: Murray Klinger

info: Murray Klinger, also known as Morris, Moses, and Moe, was the third child of Solomon Klinger and Yetta Kessler. He was born on August 18, 1910, in New York, New York. According to census records, he was living with his family in Manhattan, New York, in 1915, 1920, and 1930. On December 18, 1944, he married Ruth Beatrice Shane in New York City, New York. The two had one son together, Franklin, and the three of them were recorded as living together in Kew Gardens, New York, in the 1950 census. Murray died on May 3, 1881, in Palm Beach, Florida.

name: Ruth Beatrice Shane

info: Ruth Beatrice Shane, born Olshansky, was the wife of Murray Klinger. She was born on August 18, 1910, in Kiev, Ukraine, the second daughter of Max Olshansky and Ida Schwartz. She immigrated to the United States sometime before 1935, and is recorded in the 1940 census as living in Brooklyn, New York, with her parents. On December 18, 1944, she married Murray in New York City, New York. They had one son, Franklin, in 1946, and the family was recorded as living in Kew Gardens, New York, in 1950. Ruth died on August 7, 2001, in New York City.

name: Franklin Klinger
info: Franklin Klinger was the only child of Murray Klinger and Ruth Beatrice Shane. He was born on July 31, 1946, in New York, USA, and was recorded in the 1950 census as living in Kew Gardens, New York, with his parents. It is unclear if Franklin ever married or had children. He is still living.

info: Lillian Klinger, who went by Lillie, was the youngest child of Solomon Klinger and Yetta Kessler. She was born on January 18, 1913, in New York, New York, and is recorded as living in Manhattan, New York, with her family in the 1915, 1920, and 1930 censuses. On August 5, 1933, she married Moses Drucker, an immigrant from the same region as her parents. They had one child together, a daughter named Joan Beverly. Lillie is recorded as living in Brooklyn, New York, in the 1940 and 1950 censuses, although by 1950 she was listed as a widow. Lillie died in June of 1985, at the age of 72.

name: Moses Drucker

name: Sadie Drucker
marriage_place: Manhattan, New York City, New York, USA
info:
Sadie Drucker, born Sara, was the second wife of Solomon Kessler. She was born on March 14, 1881, in Stanislaw, in the Austrian Empire (now Ivano-Frankivs'k, Ukraine), the youngest child of Jona Skulnik and Beile Drucker (it is quite possible she is related to her step-daughter Lillian's husband, Moses Drucker, as they had the same last name and both came from Stanislaw). She used her mother's maiden name, Drucker, instead of her father's, Skulnik, likely because her parents had only had a religious marriage by the time of her birth, not a civil marriage, and so the government did not recognize her father's paternity. Sadie had one daughter in Poland, Ester Cirl Drucker. However, she was also not married, at least not legally, and the father of the child is unknown, as he was not even noted in the margins of her birth certificate as was often customary.

Sadie and Ester Cirl immigrated to the United States in 1909, departing from Hamburg, Germany aboard the S.S. Amerika on November 24, and arriving at the port of New York on December 5. They were listed in the 1920 census as living in Manhattan, New York. Sadie married Solomon Klinger on March 30, 1929, in Manhattan, and the two are recorded as living together in Manhattan in the 1930, 1940, and 1950 censuses. Sadie died on December 30, 1959.

info:
Saul Sigelschiffer was the only child of Hyman L. Sigelschiffer and Lena Klinger. He was born on October 16, 1902, in Brooklyn, New York. He attended the College of the City of New York (now City College) for his undergraduate studies, and then earned his Juris Doctor and his Doctor of Judicial Studies degrees from New York University. On July 8, 1936, he married Rita E. Weiss in Yonkers, New York. They are listed as living together in Yonkers in the 1940 and 1950 censuses. They had one daughter together, Tamara.

Saul worked as a history teacher in New York, and served as principal of several secondary schools including at Riverdale Junior High in Riverdale, New York, during the 1960s. He also served as Professor of Education at Yeshiva University, and contibuted to a number of educational journals. While teaching history, he became interested in the story of the Lincoln-Douglas debates and their impact on American history. Realizing that the whole story of the debates and their effects on the country had never been told, Saul spent more than ten years researching the subject, resulting in his publishing of the book The American Conscience: The Drama of the Lincoln-Douglas Debates in 1973.

Saul died at the age of 91, on February 12, 1994, in New York, USA.

info: Philippine Ascher, born Libe, was the second child of Jacob Ascher and Kreindel Hirschhorn. She was born in 1876 in Rzeszow, Poland, and is recorded as living there with her family in the 1880 and 1890 censuses. She married Samuel Laub, her first cousin on her father's side, in 1908 in Rzeszow, and soon afterwards the couple moved to Stuttgart, Germany. There, they had three children, Karla, Eric Jacob, and Elsa. She was still living in Stuttgart in 1936, when her son Eric Jacob immigrated to the United States. Sometime likely not long after, Philippine remarried to Leib Rubenfeld, in Stuttgart. The two of them both survived the Holocaust, although where and how is unclear. Philippine died on February 3, 1960, in Germany, at the age of 83.

name: Samuel Laub

info: Samuel Laub was the husband of Philippine Ascher. He was born on April 25, 1877, in Rzeszow, Poland, to Osias Schyja Laub and Sara Ascher. His maternal uncle was his wife's father, making him and Philippine first cousins. Samuel is recorded as living in Rzeszow on the 1880 and 1890 censuses. He married Philippine in Rzeszow in 1908, and the couple soon moved to Stuttgart, Germany, where their three children were born: Karla, Eric Jacob, and Elsa. Samuel served as a Feldwebel (a German military rank equivalent to a sergeant) in the Austro-Hungarian Army during World War I. He died on October 12, 1934, in Stuttgart, at the age of 57.

name: Karla Laub
info: Karla Laub was the oldest child of Samuel Laub and Philippine Ascher. She departed from the port at Le Verdon-sur-Mer, France, aboard the S.S. Washington, on October 26, 1939, and arrived in New York, USA, a few days later, on November 1, 1939. After arriving in the U.S., Karla changed the spelling of her first name to Carla. She soon met Eric Arthur Sander, and the two were married on December 5, 1942 in New York. They never had any children. Carla died on January 22, 1962.

name: Eric Arthur Sander
birth_place: Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Hesse, Germany
info:
Eric Arthur Sander was the husband of Karla Laub. He was born on September 21, 1912, in Frankfurt, Germany, to Siegfried Sander and Berta Franziska Wolf. Growing up, the Eric lived in Rottweil, Germany. His father was an active member of the SPD (Social Democratic Party of Germany) and was sent to the Heuberg Concentration Camp in the first wave of arrests, from March to October of 1933. At that time, the family also lost their home, and moved to Stuttgart, Germany. Five years later, in 1938, they lost their house again, due to rising antisemitism in Germany. In 1941, Eric managed to escape Germany and emigrate to the United States aboard the S.S. Mouzinho, departing from Lisbon, Portugal, on August 20 and arriving in New York, USA, on September 2. His parents were not so lucky: in 1942 they were sent to the Dachau and Ravensbruck concentration camps, and both died not long after.

Once in the United States, Eric enlisted in the military, entering the U.S. Army on November 30, 1942, and serving during World War II. He married Karla literally a few days later, on December 5, 1942, in New York. The two did not have any children together. Eric died on June 20, 2003, at the age of 90.

*an interesting discovery was that Eric's first cousin on his mother's side was Elsa Willena Wolf, who was born in Baltimore, Maryland, and married Charles Gabriel Hutzler II. Charles Gabriel Hutzler II was the third cousin of Barbara Blaustein, who married Karla's second cousin once removed David Hirschhorn (Charles Gabriel Hutzler II's great-grandmother was Betty Sonneborn née Hirsch, the sister of Barbara Blaustein's great-grandmother Hanna van Leer née Hirsch).

name: Eric Jacob Laub

On October 20 of that year, he immigrated to the United States, departing from Le Havre, France, and arriving in New York, USA, on October 27. Eric married Gertrud Jelinek in New York on October 3, 1942, and a few days later, on October 10, 1942, Eric enlisted in the U.S. Army. He was released from military service on November 20, 1945, and was recorded as living in Manhattan, New York, on the 1950 census. Eric died on December 2, 1994, in Southbury, Connecticut, at the age of 83.

info: Gertrud Jelinek, known as Trudy, was the wife of Eric Jacob Laub. She was born to Felix Jelinek and Alice Weintraub on November 19, 1918, in Vienna Austria. By April of 1940, Gertrud and Ernest had divorced, and on that year's census Gertrud was listed as living in New York City, New York, working as a maid. On October 3, 1942, she married Eric Jacob Laub in New York, where the two were listed as living together in the 1950 census. Gertrud died on May 8, 2015, at the age of 96.

name: Elsa Laub

At some point, Elsa moved to Brno, Czechoslovakia (now in the Czech Republic), and was married to David Rimpel. The pair had one daughter, Dina. On April 8, 1942, the family was deported from Brno to the Theresienstadt ghetto in Terezin, Czechoslovakia, and from there to the Auschwitz concentration camp in Oswiecim, Poland, on May 15, 1944, where Elsa was killed sometime later that year.

From there, they were transported to the Auschwitz concentration camp in Oswiecim, Poland, on May 15, 1944. name: Leib Rubenfeld
info: Leib Rubenfeld was the second husband of Philippine Ascher. He was born on June 1, 1874, in Rybotycze, Poland, to Salom Rubenfeld and Groelle Weitzner. He married his first wife, Josefine Weiss, on October 19, 1905, in Heilbronn, Germany, where they were living. Together, they at least two children, Sigmund and Grete. It is unclear when Josefine died, but Leib at some point became a widower, and remarried to Philippine Ascher, in Stuttgart, Germany. The two of them both survived the Holocaust, although where and how is unclear. Leib died in Germany on November 3, 1963, at the age of 89.

He was noted as living in Rzeszow on the 1880 and 1890 censuses, but sometime later he moved to Vienna, Austria, where on December 12, 1909, he married Leja Pasternak. They had four children: Heinrich, Karoline Sara, Dina, and Wilma Ruth. On June 5, 1942, Selig and his wife were deported from Vienna to the Izbica Ghetto in Eastern Poland. He died likely not long after, either at Izbica or at the Sobibor concentration camp, around 1942.

At some point, she moved to Vienna, Austria, where on December 12, 1909, she married Selig. The pair had four children together: Heinrich, Karoline Sara, Dina, and Wilma Ruth. On June 5, 1942, Leja and her husband were deported from Vienna to the Izbica Ghetto in Eastern Poland. She died likely not long after, either at Izbica or at the Sobibor concentration camp in eastern Poland, around 1942.

name: Heinrich Ascher
info: Heinrich Ascher was the oldest child, and only son, of Selig Ascher and Leja Pasternak. He was born in Vienna, Austria, on November 17, 1910. Around March of 1934, Heinrich married Julie Picher at the Stadttempel synagogue in Vienna, and not long after they immigrated to Palestine, arriving on April 16, 1934. On September 28, 1941, in Jerusalem, Heinrich became a naturalized citizen of Palestine. A few months later, in January of 1942, he and Julie divorced. They did not have any children. After that, it is unclear what happened to Heinrich, who may have gone by the name Tzvi in Israel. At the time of his sister Karoline's death, he was still alive and living in Ra'anana, Israel. It is unknown if he ever remarried or had any children, or when he died.

name: Julie Picher
info: Julie Picher, also known as Yael, was the wife of Heinrich Ascher. She was born on July 4, 1914, in Vienna, Austria. She married Heinrich around March of 1934 at the Stadttempel synagogue in Vienna, and the two soon moved to Palestine, arriving on April 16, 1934. Julie became a naturalized citizen of Palestine on September 28, 1941, but a few months later, in January of 1942, she and Heinrich got a divorce. At some point, Julie moved to Egypt, where in 1946 she remarried to a Yugoslavian citizen who was living there. By this point, she had lost contact with Heinrich and was unaware of his whereabouts. It is unknown what happened to her after this, if she ever had any children, or when she died.

name: Karoline Ascher
info:
Karoline Ascher was the second child of Selig Ascher and Leja Pasternak, their eldest daughter. She was born on March 16, 1912 in Vienna, Austria. In the fall of 1932, Karoline began her medical studies at the University of Vienna, and studied there until the Spring of 1937, the fifth and final year of her studies. However, she was forced to abandon her almost completed studies and leave the university without a degree due to National Socialist policies.

She was able to emigrate to England with a domestic permit, and worked there in Wallasey, Cheshire, England, as a maid and a cook, before being able to put her medical training to use as a nurse and midwife. In 1950, Karoline returned to Vienna, completing her medical studies and earned her Doctor of Medicine degree from the University of Vienna on February 8, 1952.

In 1955, she immigrated to the United States, where she completed an internship in Rhode Island and a residency at the New Britain General Hospital in New Britain, Connecticut. On July 16, 1960, while living in Hartford, Connecticut, Karoline became a naturalized U.S. citizen. She would go on to work as a doctor for many years at Cedar Crest Hospital in Newington, Connecticut, and then at the Rocky Hill Veterans Hospital in Rocky Hill, Connecticut, before retiring in 1977. Karoline never married or had any children, and died on April 23, 1988, in New Britain, Connecticut, at the age of 76.

name: Dina Ascher

name: Wilma Ruth Ascher
info: Wilma Ruth Ascher was the fourth and youngest child of Selig Ascher and Leja Pasternak. She was born on January 12, 1921 in Vienna, Austria. Sometime between 1934 and 1938 she met her future husband, Max Schneider, and in early 1939, after the annexation of Austria in March of 1938, the two were able to emigrate to England thanks to the Hashomer Hatzair socialist-Zionist organization. There, they likely lived in internment camps, and were married on August 2, 1941, in Leamington Spa, England. Both survived the Holocaust, and in 1947 they moved back to Austria. They never had any children. Wilma died on July 19, 2002, in Vienna, Austria.

name: Max Schneider
info:
Max Schneider was the husband of Wilma Ruth Ascher. He was born on December 4, 1921, in Vienna, Austria, to Adolf Abraham Schneider and Josefine Grunfeld. He had two younger siblings, a sister named Gertrude and a brother named Robert, and the three were raised in Vienna in a non-religious Jewish family. As a child, Max was a member of the Red Falcons, a group for children of socialist families, until the group was banned in 1934, upon which time he joined the also-illegal Communist Youth of Austria (KJÖ) organization. Max dropped out of school to start an apprenticeship, and sometime between then and 1938 he met his future wife, Ruth. It was she that brought him to the Hashomer Hatzair socialist-Zionist youth organization, through which the two of them were able to emigrate to England in early 1939, after the annexation of Austria in March of 1938.

In England, Max worked as a farm laborer until the outset of World War II. In 1940, he was interned in England, as well as for a time Canada, before being returned to England. He began working as a metalworker in the arms industry, and married Ruth on August 2, 1941 in Leamington Spa, England. After the Moscow Declaration of October, 1943, Max volunteered for the British Army. Once finished with his training, he served in a Scottish infantry unit in France, Belgium, and Holland under the name of Peter Shelley, helping to liberate his homeland. However, in April of 1945, he was severely wounded in northern Germany. He was awarded for his bravery. Max and Ruth both survived the war, as did Max's younger sister, Gertrude. Unfortunately, Max's parents and younger brother did not. They were deported from Vienna on February 6, 1942, and were killed in an extermination camp near Riga, Latvia in early 1943.

In early 1947, Max and Ruth were able to move back to Austria, and in 1948 Max earned the high school diploma he had not been able to receive. In 1947, Max became active in the Communist Party of Austria, holding multiple positions in various regional offices, including serving in Vienna as the regional secretary in the 1960s. However, he was voted out of office in 1968 due to his support of the Prague Spring, and he left the party. He went on to work in the private sector, and after his retirement started serving in schools as a contemporary witness against fascism. He was regularly invited to give lectures and participate in discussions as a survivor of the Holocaust. Due to this work, Max was awarded the Golden Medal of Merit by the state of Vienna. Max died in Vienna, Austria on June 12, 2010, at the age of 88.

name: Eliasz Chaim Hirschhorn
info:
Eliasz Chaim Hirschhorn was the sixth child of Salomon Hirschhorn and Liebe Sara Both.He was born on June 24, 1867, in Rzeszow, Poland, and was recorded as living there with his family in the 1870 and 1880 censuses. According to notes written by Isidor Hirschhorn (his nephew), he moved to the United States for a time, before returning to Poland, which tracks with the fact that he is not listed on the 1890 Rzeszow census with his family, but reappears on the 1902 census as living with them. When exactly he was in the United States, and what he did there, is unclear, as is whether or not he ever married or had children. It is also unknown when Eliasz Chaim died.

*interestingly enough, there was another man named Elias Hirschhorn born in Rzeszow just two months after Eliasz Chaim, on August 20, 1867. This Elias Hirschhorn did get married and had three sons, Maurycy, Ignacy, and Fryderyk, and currently has living descendants in Belgium today. He was the son of a Lipe Hirschhorn, who himself was the son of a Mojzesz Hirschhorn. While it is likely that this family is related to ours, as they were all neighbors in Rzeszow and shared a last name, it is unclear exactly how they are related, although Mojzesz Hirschhorn would have been the same generation as Abraham Wolf Hirschhorn, so it is possible they were brothers. The families certainly would have known each other, at the very least.

name: Ephraim Hirschhorn
children: Isidor Solomon Hirschhorn, David Hirschhorn
info:
Ephraim Hirschhorn was the tenth child of Isak Salomon Hirschhorn and Liebe Sara Both. He was born on April 22, 1874 in Rzeszow, Poland. He appeared as living with his family in Rzeszow in the 1880, 1890, 1902, and 1910 censuses. By 1910, they were living in a building owned by Shulem Rosenwasser, the uncle of Ephraim's future wife Amelia Kornfeld, who he met when she went to live with her Uncle Shulem at the age of 14, after the deaths of both of her parents. 

Ephraim was a successful banker in Rzeszow; he was the manager of the Austro-Hungarian government bank in the city, and was well-known and well-respected. He was also well educated and well traveled, and was an ardent Zionist, involved in numerous organizations in Rzeszow including Poale Zion, a movement of Marxist-Zionist Jewish workers. In addition, he helped to found a Jewish newspaper in Rzeszow, although it only seems to have run for a few issues. Ephraim and Amelia were engaged in 1914. He was 40, she was 21. Amelia's Uncle Shulem disapproved of the union largely because of Ephraim's age, his involvement in the Zionist movement which Shulem was against, and because Ephraim was not very religious. 

Before they could get married, in late 1914, they fled Rzeszow to Prague, Czech Republic (then part of the Austrian Empire). Upon arriving in Prague, in December of 1914, they had a very rushed religious marriage, but did not have their official civil marriage until December 30, 1917. They had two sons in Prague, Isak Salomon (later Isidor) and David. Life in Prague was hard, as they were immigrants and did not have papers, not to mention that it was during World War I, but Ephraim found work at a refugee office and they were able to support themselves. They knew it was temporary. They had intended to return to Rzeszow. However, Amelia's brother Benjamin had by then established himself in the United States and wrote to her that they should join him. It took Amelia six months to persudae Ephraim to immigrate to the United States, but eventually she did.

They obtained their visas and left Prague, stopping first in Stuttgart to visit Ephraim's niece Philippine Ascher and her family, the Laubs, and then in Nuremberg to visit his brother Moses Jozef Hirschhorn and his family, before arriving in Cherbourg, France, in December of 1921. Upon arrival, they sat through a week long inspection, after which they were finally allowed to board the boat. However, after boarding, they received a message that they would have to debark: the border had been closed, and their sons would have been allowed to leave as they were Czech citizens, but Ephraim and Amelia would have to stay behind because they were Polish citizens. The whole family got off the boat, and remained in Cherbourg for six months, from December of 1921 until June of 1922. The day before their French visa would have run out, they were able to renew it. Eventually, they boarded the S.S. Majestic and set sail for the United States on June 28, 1922. They arrived in New York on July 4, 1922, and were welcomed by fireworks celebrating American Independence Day. The whole trip, Ephraim complained, but Amelia told him that if she could manage, he would be able to as well.

They were met in the United States by Amelia's brother Benjamin, who had been there since 1912. Ephraim and Benjamin did not get along well, but the family settled in to Newark, New Jersey, where Ephraim lived for the rest of his life. He did not take well to the United States and always harbored hopes of returning to Rzeszow, or making aliyah to Israel. Ephraim never learned English, and although Benjamin found him a job in a factory, Ephraim quit after a few days as he found it unfitting for a man with his background and experience to be working a job like that. He suffered health issues, including two strokes, the second of which caused his death in New Jersey on March 9, 1941. He was 66 years old.

name: Amelia Kornfeld
children: Isidor Solomon Hirschhorn, David Hirschhorn
info:
Amelia Kornfeld was the wife of Ephraim Hirschhorn. She was born on April 7, 1893, in the small town of Olpiny, Poland, to Solomon David Kornfeld and Beila Rosenwasser, their oldest child of four and only daughter. Her parents had been introduced to each other by the famous Rabbi Chaim Halberstam of Nowy Sacz, where Beila's family was from. He was friends with both Solomon's father, Berl Kornfeld, and Beila's father, Joseph Rosenwasser. Amelia grew up in Olpiny, and went to Catholic school where the nun's who taught her called her by her mother's last name, Rosenwasser, since her parents had only had a religious marriage, not a civil one, so their marriage was not officially recognized. From a youing age Amelia had to help out with the housework and take care of her younger brothers, as her mother was often out of town peddling wares.

Amelia's mother died of tuberculosis in 1906, when Amelia was just 13, and her father died the next year of complications from a surgery. He had gone to Vienna for the operation and never returned. After both parents died, Amelia and her siblings were divided up among their mother's siblings: Benjamin went to live with an uncle in Nowy Wisnicz (likely Israel Rosenwasser, with his wife Gitel Gutfreund and their sons Simche and Judah), Joseph went to Nowy Sacz (likely to his aunt Scheindel Rosenwasser, with her husband Isaak Borgenicht and their children Mendel Leiser, Israel, and Perl), while Israel, at just 3 years old, was left with a Jewish woman who lived near Rzeszow, Poland, who they paid to take care of him. Amelia was also sent to Rzeszow, to live with her Uncle Shulem Rosenwasser, along with his wife Feige Reichwald and their two children, Zalman and Regina.

Shulem had a bit of a temper, but his wife was always kind to Amelia. Similarly, while she never got along too well with Regina, who was jealous of Amelia's good looks, she got along really well with Zalman, who was involved in the Zionist movement in Rzeszow. However, Shulem disapproved of Zionism and would often get angry with Zalman, and Amelia would often step in between the two to protect Zalman. Shulem ran a general store in Rzeszow, where Amelia was put to work. Instead of going to school, she learned to be a businesswoman. Above the store were apartments that Shulem rented out, including to the family of Ephraim Hirschhorn, who was involved in the Zionist movement with Zalman. Amelia and Ephraim fell in love, and were engaged in 1914, although Uncle Shulem disapproved of their engagement because Ephraim was almopst 20 years her senior, was not very religious, and was a Zionist.

Before they could get married, in late 1914, they fled Rzeszow to Prague, Czech Republic (then part of the Austrian Empire). Upon arriving in Prague, in December of 1914, they had a very rushed religious marriage, but did not have their official civil marriage until December 30, 1917. They had two sons in Prague, Isak Salomon (later Isidor) and David. Life in Prague was hard, as they were immigrants and did not have papers, not to mention that it was during World War I, but Ephraim found work at a refugee office and they were able to support themselves. They knew it was temporary. They had intended to return to Rzeszow. However, Amelia's brother Benjamin had by then established himself in the United States and wrote to her that they should join him. It took Amelia six months to persuade Ephraim to immigrate to the United States, but eventually she did.

They obtained their visas and left Prague, taking trains through Germany before arriving in Cherbourg, France, in December of 1921. Upon arrival, they sat through a week long inspection, after which they were finally allowed to board the boat. However, after boarding, they received a message that they would have to debark: the border had been closed, and their sons would have been allowed to leave as they were Czech citizens, but Ephraim and Amelia would have to stay behind because they were Polish citizens. The whole family got off the boat, and remained in Cherbourg for six months, from December of 1921 until June of 1922. During that time, Amelia learned French and took care of the family by cooking, cleaning, sewing, and taking on other odd jobs. The day before their French visa would have run out, they were able to renew them. Eventually, they boarded the S.S. Majestic and set sail for the United States on June 28, 1922. They arrived in New York on July 4, 1922, and were welcomed by fireworks celebrating American Independence Day.

They were met in the United States by Amelia's brother Benjamin, who had been there since 1912. Ephraim and Benjamin did not get along well, but the family settled in to Newark, New Jersey. Ephraim was not able to find work, so it was up to Amelia to take care of the family, and she did so by running a bed and breakfast out of their apartment. She raised her sons in Newark, where Ephraim died in 1941. Fifteen years later, Amelia remarried to Abraham Schneider, on June 10, 1956. Amelia lived a long a full life, dying in Baltimore, Maryland on April 24, 1983, at the age of 90.

Isidor Solomon Hirschhorn, born Isak Salomon, was the older son of Ephraim Hirschhorn and Amelia Kornfeld. He was born in Prague, in the Austrian Empire (now in the Czech Republic), on October 25, 1915. In 1921, his family left Prague, taking trains through Germany before arriving in Cherbourg, France, in December of 1921.
