They arrived in New York on July 4, 1922, and were welcomed by fireworks celebrating American Independence Day.

Isidor lived in the United States for the rest of his life. He worked as a high school teacher and a chemist, and enjoyed sailing, painting, and photography. He married Ellen Sylvia Stein on April 2, 1947, and they had two children together: Susan Beth and Robert E.. Isidor died in Maplewood, New Jersey, on June 22, 2007, at the age of 91.

In 1921, his family left Prague, taking trains through Germany before arriving in Cherbourg, France, in December of 1921. Upon arrival, they sat through a week long inspection, after which they were finally allowed to board the boat. However, after boarding, they received a message that they would have to debark: the border had been closed, and while David and his brother would be allowed to leave as they were Czech citizens, their parents would have to stay behind because they were Polish citizens. The whole family got off the boat, and remained in Cherbourg for six months, from December of 1921 until June of 1922. During that time, Amelia learned French and took care of the family. The day before their French visa would have run out, they were able to renew them. Eventually, they boarded the S.S. Majestic and set sail for the United States on June 28, 1922. They arrived in New York on July 4, 1922, and were welcomed by fireworks celebrating American Independence Day.

David lived in the United States for the rest of his life, aside from his time stationed overseas while serving in the U.S. Army Air Forces during World War II, from which he was honorably discharged on January 11, 1946. He married Barbara Evelyn Blaustein in Baltimore, Maryland, on October 23, 1955, and they had four children together: Daniel Blaustein, Michael Joseph, Deborah Sophie, and Sarah Beth. *although no records have been found to prove this yet, it is possible that Hersch Zwi Both was the brother of Liebe Sara Both, who married his wife's brother Isak Salomon Hirschhorn. Hersch Zwi and Liebe Sara share a last name and were both born in Rzeszow withing a year or two of each other. name: Josef Markus Schipper
info:
Josef Markus Schipper was the fourth child, and only son, of Moses Wolf Schipper and Rachel Schifra Sontag. He was born on February 28, 1926, in Rzeszow, Poland. At some point during the Holocaust, Josef was captured and sent to a concentration camp. On August 4, 1944, he arrived at the Flossenbürg concentration camp, in Flossenbürg, Germany. It is unclear if he was at a different camp before that, or if this was the first one he was sent to. From Flossenbürg, he was sent to the Natzweiler-Struthof concentration camp, in what was then a part of Germany but is now in Bas-Rhin, Alsace, France. He arrived there on October 12, 1944, and just over a month later, on November 23, 1944, the camp was liberated by the French 1st Army and the U.S. 6th Army Group.

After the Holocaust, Josef was taken in by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA) as a displaced person, and was sent to Sweden sometime after July 20, 1945. However, he died not long afterward, on February 10, 1946, in Lärbro, Sweden, likely from some type of illness. Josef was one of the many sick and wounded refugees and victims of Nazi concentration camps that were sent to the newly-built field hospital in Lärbro. Josef was not even 20 years old when he died. He was buried in the cemetery of the Lärbro Church, where a memorial honors Josef and the eight other Jews who are buried there.

They had three children together in Rzeszow, Gisela (later Kate), Henne, and Rozia (later Rose), before immigrating to the United States. Ester departed aboard the S.S. Oldenburg from the port at Bremen, Germany, in mid-May of 1895 with two surviving daughters, Gisela and Rozia, following her husband. They arrived in New York, USA, on May 29, 1895. Once in the United States, Ester and Isak had three more children: Edith, Harry, and Abraham. Ester lived in Newark, New Jersey, for the rest of her life, being recorded as living there in the 1900, 1905, 1910, 1020, 1930, and 1940 censuses. She was an active member of Newark's Rzeszow Landsmanschaft until she died at the age of 94 on February 14, 1961, in Newark.

Isak immigrated alone to the United States, sometime around 1894, and was soon followed by his wife and two surviving daughters, Gisela and Rozia, in May of 1895. Once in the United States, Isak and Ester had three more children: another daughter named Edith, and two sons, Harry and Abraham. name: Chaim Both
children: Henryk Maksymilian Both, Fanny Both
info:
Chaim Both, also known as Joachim, was the seventh and youngest child of Hersch Zwi Both and Gruene Hirschhorn, and may have been the twin brother of Liebe. He was born on May 8, 1876, in Rzeszow, Poland, and was recorded as living there on the 1880, 1890, and 1902 censuses. On June 1, 1907, he married Marjem Zeimer in Jaroslaw, Poland. They had one child together in Jaroslaw, a son named Henryk Maksymilian (later Max), before moving to Munich, Germany, arriving on September 15, 1908. Once in Munich, Chaim and Marjem had another child, a daughter named Franziska (later Fanny).

In October of 1908, Chaim Both opened a men's clothing and fashion store with his brother-in-law Jonas Zeimer, who had moved to Munich with them. By July of 1909, Chaim was the sole owner of the shop, and in 1912 they opened up a second location. Around 1930, his son became a partner in the business.

In the evening of November 9, 1938, the windows of many of Munich's Jewish shops were smashed by members of the S.A., including the windows of Chaim Both's shop, above which the family lived. The perpetrators were chased away by patrons of neighboring restaurants, but later that night ten S.A. members returned. Four of them forced their way into the Both family's apartment above the store. When Chaim, Marjem, and Max returned home that night at around midnight, Chaim was knocked down and dragged into his apartment while Marjem was forced onto the street, and she and Max were prevented from entering.

Chaim was held in a room of his apartment by an S.A. man named Schenk. According to Schenk, a sudden movement by Both caused him to fire his gun. Whether this is really what really occured is doubtful, as a later forensic investigation concluded that Chaim died from a relatively close-ranged shot to the forehead. Regardless, Chaim was fatally wounded that night, in the early hours of November 10, 1938, at the age of 62.

name: Marjem Zeimer
children: Henryk Maksymilian Both, Fanny Both
info:
Marjem Zeimer, also known as Maria, was the wife of Chaim Both. She was born on September 30, 1880, in Jaroslaw, Poland, the older of two children born to Wolf Zeimer and Rebecca Turnheim. She married Chaim on June 1, 1907, in Jaroslaw, where they had their first child, Henryk Maksymilian (later Max). Marjem, along with her husband, son, and brother Jonas, soon moved to Munich, Germany, arriving on September 15, 1908. There, Marjem gave birth to her second child, a daughter named Franziska (later Fanny).

In October of 1908, shortly after arriving in Munich, Marjem's husband and brother opened a men's clothing and fashion retailer together. The family business prospered, and by 1930 they had opened a second location, bought the building the first location was based, and her son Max had become a partner. However, things changed on November 9, 1938. That night, the windows of many of Munich's Jewish shops were smashed by members of the S.A., including the windows of the Both's shop, above which the family lived. The perpetrators were chased away by patrons of neighboring restaurants, but later that night ten S.A. members returned. Four of them forced their way into the Both family's apartment above the store. When Marjem, Chaim, and Max returned home that night at around midnight, Chaim was knocked down and dragged into his apartment while Marjem was forced onto the street, and she and Max were prevented from entering. Chaim was murdered in the early hours of the morning.

After that night, Marjem and Max were forced to vacate their apartment, and a month or two later the Both & Zeimer retailer of men's clothing was acquired by a non-Jewish German man. While Marjem's children were both able to flee Germany in the coming year, Marjem was not so lucky. On November 20, 1941, she was deported from Munich to Kaunas, Lithuania, with about 1,000 other Jewish men, women, and children, where she was murdered in a mass shooting just five days later, on November 25, 1941.

name: Henryk Maksymilian Both
info:
Henryk Maksymilian Both, later known as Max, was the older child of Chaim Both and Marjem Zeimer. He was born in Jaroslaw, Poland, on April 7, 1908, and moved with his family to Munich, Germany, at just five months old, arriving on September 15, 1908. There, his father, along with his uncle Jonas Zeimer, opened a men's clothing and fashion retailer, and around 1930 Max joined the family business, which by then was booming.

Things changed for the family on November 9, 1938. That night, the windows of many of Munich's Jewish shops were smashed by members of the S.A., including the windows of the Both's shop, above which the family lived. The perpetrators were chased away by patrons of neighboring restaurants, but later that night ten S.A. members returned. Four of them forced their way into the Both family's apartment above the store. When Max returned home that night at around midnight with his parents, Chaim was knocked down and dragged into his apartment while Marjem was forced onto the street, and she and Max were prevented from entering. Chaim was murdered in the early hours of the morning.

After that night, Marjem and Max were forced to vacate their apartment, and a month or two later the Both & Zeimer retailer of men's clothing was acquired by a non-Jewish German man. Max managed to emigrate to England in 1939, where he lived for the rest of his life. In 1947, Max married Hildegard Reiss, another German immigrant, in London, England. They had multiple sons, although exactly how many and what their names are remain unknown. Max died in London on April 10, 1972, at the age of 74.

name: Hildegard Reiss
birth_place: Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Hesse, Germany
info: Hildegard Reiss was the wife of Henryk Maksymilian Both. She was born on March 10, 1926, in Frankfurt, Germany, the daughter of Yehuda Reiss. From 1939 to 1942, Hildegard was living in Sutton, England, as an "internee at liberty," meaning she was an "enemy alien" living in England who was deemed low risk and was thus not interned, but was allowed to stay mostly free as long as she followed certain restrictions. She married her husband in London, England, in 1947, and they had multiple sons together, although exactly how many and what their names are remain unknown. Hildegard died in London on July 19, 2016, at the age of 90.

name: Fanny Both
children: Jerry M. Kammer, Ronald M. Kammer
info:
Fanny Both, born Franziska, was the younger child of Chaim Both and Marjem Zeimer. She was born on December 16, 1909, in Munich, Germany, where her family had moved to just the year before. There, her father and uncle, Jonas Zeimer, ran a men's clothing and fashion retailer. Fanny herself was studying at the Meisterschule fur Deutsche Moden (Master School for German Fashions), but in 1935 she was kicked out of the school because she was Jewish. She married Fritz Kammer (later Frank) in December of 1936.

On November 9, 1938, Fanny parents and brother returned home from a night out to find their shop's windows smashed in and their home invaded. Her father was pulled inside their apartment, while her mother and brother weer barred from entering, and her father was shot and murdered. Not long after, the family was forced to evacuate their home, and their shop was acquired by a non-Jewish German man. Fanny and Fritz managed to emigrate to the United States in 1939, departing from Southampton, England, on August 26 aboard the S.S. Veendam and arriving in New York, USA, on September 6.

Once in the United States, Fanny and Frank had two children, Jerry M. and Ronald M.. The family was noted as living in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, in the 1950 census. Every few years, they would visit her brother in England, including in 1950, 1954, and 1956. Fanny died in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, on March 20, 1973, at the age of 63.

name: Frank Kammer
children: Jerry M. Kammer, Ronald M. Kammer
info: Fritz Kammer, who later went by Frank, was the husband of Fanny Both. He was born in Munich, Germany, on December 31, 1907, to Moritz Kammer and Helene Krieger. His paternal aunt, Malwine Kammer, was married to the German painter Otto Maria Porsche. Fritz married Fanny in Munich in December of 1936. The two of them immigrated to the United States not long after Fanny's father was murdered by the S.A., departing from Southampton, England, aboard the S.S. Veendam on August 26, 1939, and arriving in New York, USA, on September 6, 1939. After arriving, he and his wife had two children, Jerry M. and Ronald M.. Frank, as he was called in the United States, was enlisted into the U.S. Army on October 16, 1943, and served in Austria during World War II before being honorably discharged on January 11, 1946. Frank died on February 6, 1949, in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, at just 41 years old.

name: Jerry M. Kammer

info: Jerry M. Kammer was the older son of Frank Kammer and Fanny Both. He was born on March 3, 1943, in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, where he was recorded as living on the 1950 census.
